Title: Lot 1 Network Management
Description:
The Council of the London Boroughs of Waltham Forest, and other participating organisations ("the Authority") is seeking Tenders from suitably experienced and qualified organisations for appointment to the Framework Agreement for the Provision of Manned Security Guarding, Supply Installation and Maintenance of CCTV, Network Management, Lone Working, Fire Alarm and Door Entry Systems for the following Lots:-
Lot One (a): Wireless Services / Provision of Fibre
Lot One (b); Cloud Services

The Framework shall commence on 1st July 2019 and, subject to satisfactory performance, shall continue up to and including 30th June 2023 ("the Framework Period").  


A maximum of four (4) providers are to be appointed to each of these Lots of the Framework. The Framework is available on a national basis to any public sector organisation within the United Kingdom. 
	
All providers appointed to each of the lots are required as a minimum to have the capacity to deliver the service on a national level throughout the United Kingdom. Organisations can tender for one or both lots.


Organisations shall be experienced in providing similar services and shall also be required, as part of their Tender, to complete a Selection Questionnaire containing information about their economic and financial standing, technical capability and other general information. This information will be assessed to establish that the organisation is financially viable and technically capable of undertaking a service of the nature covered by the relevant Lot. Also, as a pre-condition to their Tenders being evaluated, organisations will have to satisfy the mandatory and discretionary grounds for exclusion contained in the Selection Questionnaire.

The Authority carries out financial appraisals of all organisations that Tender for the Authority's contracts to ensure that such organisations satisfy the Authority's minimum standards of economic and financial standing. In this instance the Authority has set the following financial thresholds as follows:-

Lot 1 (a): Minimum of £1,500,000 annual turnover in last 2 years
Lot 1 (b): Minimum of £600,000 annual turnover in last 2 years

Title: ICT12804 - Core Support Services
Description:
Delivery of:
•	Service Desk and Desk Side Support services, including support for Customer Information Screens, Audio/Visual equipment and Meeting Rooms.
•	continuity of service for TfL;
•	the technical resources for its services that TfL needs as and when required
•	service performance to agreed service levels; 
•	improvements to existing services in line with business requirements and TfL's strategic direction; and
•	recommendations/guidance on leveraging new technology and/or ways of working to further optimise TfL's Core Support Services.
•	Platform to enable the objectives outlined in section 2.5 to be achieved.

Drivers for Change
Adoption of:
•	a CSS Contract model that, where applicable, is based on the principles of joint working, collaboration and co-operation, and which is designed to provide opportunities for TfL and the Supplier to work together openly, delivering continuous product/service improvement and innovation;
•	industry best practice standards; 
•	standard best practice tools, seamlessly integrated across the supply configuration chain, delivering effective monitoring and management reporting;
•	to reduce costs; and
•	to improve the service for TfL's customers.

During the term of the Contract, and aligned with TfL's strategic direction, TfL may engage with the successful Bidder to review and potentially provide additional services from the Bidder.  These potential services are not included in the current contract scope but may be requested via the Change Control Procedure. These potential services will not be evaluated or priced as part of this ITN.
The detail, or timeframes, for these potential services cannot be fully detailed at present but the potential scope of the services encompasses all the core transactional activities performed by the Technology Service Operations (TSO) team within TfL.  The TSO team is responsible for the full end to end support of IT services (business and technical) provisioned within TfL. This covers all the stages of service lifecycle, from inception/planning, through design, build, transition, operation, maintain, optimise and ultimately decommission.

Title: Chenderit School Academy Trust - Tender for Catering Services
Description:
The successful supplier will be required to provide catering services for Chenderit School.

Chenderit School is a mixed 11-18 secondary school on the outskirts of Northamptonshire County Council Education authority and just 3 miles from Banbury in Oxfordshire. The school became an academy in 2012.

The tender project is seeking to appoint a Supplier whose initiative and innovation will be welcomed for the provision of service within the existing facilities for the 1030 students on roll and 109 teaching and support staff, with a focus on exciting new food concepts to satisfy a wide range of pupil tastes and dietary requirements. The client would wish the successful supplier to review the current range of services offered and make recommendations accordingly.

The contract being tendered is for three years in duration from 1.1.2020 to 31.12.2022 and will operate as a guaranteed performance contract, with the successful Supplier offering the Client a guaranteed return/cost per annum for the provision of catering services.

The academic year is based on a calendar of 195 days. Five days are to be used for staff professional development which means that School will be open to receive students for the legal minimum of 190 days.

The contract offered covers the scope for the provision of all school catering services, which currently includes breakfast, morning break, lunch, hospitality and free issue requirements. Free School Meals are to be charged on consumption numbers. There may be a small requirement for hospitality and this will be charged at net food cost.

Whilst the client prioritises value for money as a key objective of the competitive tender process, the governing body is not obliged to accept the lowest price.

As a school continually seeking ways to improve and develop the ethos and environment for students and staff, to give them the facilities they deserve and need to meet the challenges of the 21st Century, any consideration regarding inward capital investment as part of the supplier's tender submission would be welcomed.

Please be advised that the catering service is currently contracted to ABM Catering Ltd.

Please be advised that the Client has a minimum requirement for a supplier's employer's liability/public liability and professional indemnity insurance of 10 000 000 GBP.

Please be advised that this contract will be let on a 3 + 2 years basis.

Please be advised that there are currently 8 staff employed to deliver the catering service and there are no current catering staff in the LGPS.
Additional Text:
Interest in the selection process should be expressed via email only to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk clearly stating within this email which contract / notice you are referring to. Please also provide, as a minimum, a contact name, full company postal address and telephone number.

The Selection Questionnaire and associated documents can be obtained at: https://litmuspartnership.co.uk/sq/chenderit/

The closing date for receipt of the Selection Questionnaire is 7.6.2019 (12:00). Suppliers are required to ensure that documents are obtained and returned to The Litmus Partnership Limited, by email to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk by the above closing date and time.

Documents in respect of economic / financial standing (where indicated in the Selection Questionnaire) shall be returned to The Litmus Partnership Limited, by email to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk by the above closing date and time.

It will be the Supplier's responsibility to obtain any necessary documents in order to submit a response by the closing date and time.

Title: Alternative Futures Group - Tender for Catering and Cleaning Services
Description:
Alternative Futures Group operate 6 independent hospitals in the North West, also known as treatment and recovery centres due to the nature of the pathway the individuals are on, providing planning and support for the journey towards citizenship and community participation.

Alternative Futures Group is looking for a contractor who will be their partner in excellence, providing a high-quality environment in which the Service Users at the Independent Hospitals can achieve their potential.

The successful tenderer will be required to provide catering and cleaning services at all 6 hospitals that form part of Alternative Futures Group, providing a breakdown of cost for specific buildings:

- Fir Trees,

- Lea Court,

- Meadow Park,

- Mill Brook,

- Oak Lodge,

- Weaver Lodge.

The Contractor shall provide catering and cleaning services to the Treatment and Recovery Centres that clearly support Alternative Futures Group operations, meet the highest infection control standards and strongly align with the Group's values.

The contract will commence on 1.10.2019 for a period of three years, with an option to extend on a 1 + 1 basis. The value of the contract is 2 000 000 GBP. However, further services may be added to the contract as and when.

The successful Supplier will be expected to provide the catering and cleaning services within these additional sites using the same costing model, ratios, etc. that were applied to the successful bid at the point of tender submission. The duration of contract for these sites will not be increased and they will join the contract for the remaining contract period that exists at the point of entry.

Investment is not actively sought, but may be required to enhance and further the service, should the bidder think it requires it.

We are seeking a suitably experienced Supplier who has current experience of working within the Care and NHS market place, ideally with a strong operational base within the North of England, thus allowing for responsive, contract support and management of catering staff.

The successful Supplier will be required to formally report each month on catering standard performance and operational matters, ensuring Alternative Futures Group is fully informed about all issues related to delivery of the catering and cleaning service.
Additional Text:
Interest in the tender process should be expressed via e-mail only to tenders@litmuspartnership.co.uk clearly stating within this email which contract/notice you are referring to. Please also provide, as a minimum, a contact name, full company postal address and telephone number.

After interest has been expressed via email you will be given access to the tender documents at the above link.

The closing date for receipt of tender bids is 28.6.2019 (12:00). Suppliers are required to ensure that documents are obtained and bids submitted by the above closing date and time.

It will be the Supplier's responsibility to obtain any necessary documents in order to submit a response by the closing date and time.

Delivery of the biennial Science Sampling Test (SST) and the Technical Pre-test (TPT) is required at the end of Key Stage 2 in 2020. The contract includes printing, collation, distribution, administration and coding. 
The purpose of the SST is to estimate national performance in science at the end of KS2, with respect to the KS2 programme of study for science.
The purpose of the TPT is to provide data on the performance of all items included in the trial test papers, in order to inform future SST construction.
Attachments: ITQ.docx Clarification Questions.docx
Additional Text:
Queries about the contract should be emailed to

Natalie.downing@education.gov.uk or KS2Science.SAMPLING@education.gov.uk

Title: University of Southampton Provision of a GCxGC and GC High Resolution Mass Spectrometry Solution
Description:
The purpose of this procurement is to obtain strategic equipment, in the form of multi-inlet gas chromatography and high resolution mass spectrometry. With an aim to deliver qualitative and quantitative analysis of novel and strategically important chemistries and that will be a unique capability within the UK academic sector.  

A multi-institutional team has been assembled to enable the vision for a regional, then national Centre of Excellence (CoE) for multi-inlet gas chromatography and high resolution mass spectrometry. The team has considerable scientific prestige and esteem, facility management expertise and training, established interdisciplinary and industrial collaborations and many links to EPSRC and RSC networks.

A unique suite of high specification instrumentation is requested to fulfil the aim of the vision of a CoE as described above. Advanced automated sample introduction techniques, multi-dimensional chromatography (for separation of complex mixtures) and advanced high resolution mass spectrometry (for compound identification) will be required to deliver this new capability.
Additional Text:
E-Tendering Portal: The University is utilising an electronic tendering tool, In-Tend (https://intendhost.co.uk/ universityofsouthampton) to manage this procurement and to communicate with potential suppliers and/or tenderers (as appropriate).  

All documentation in relation to this tender can be downloaded from In-Tend. 

Potential suppliers/tenderers are advised that there will be no hard copy documents issued and all communications with the University, including the submission of Selection Stage and/or Invitation to Tender responses will be conducted via In-Tend.  

Regular monitoring of the portal is the responsibility of the potential supplier/tenderer. 

If you are not already registered as a supplier with the University of Southampton, you will need to register in In-Tend in order to access the procurement documentation. 

Once you have logged in as a supplier: click on 'Tenders'; locate the relevant project; and click 'View Details'. Once you are in the project screen, you will be able to register your organisation against the project and access all documentation by clicking 'Express Interest'. 

Potential suppliers/tenderers are advised that formal expressions of interest in the project must be by way of completion and return of the relevant documents via In-Tend. 

Further instructions for the submission of responses are below:  

To submit your return: 

1. Log in 

2. Click 'Tenders' 

3. Locate the relevant project 

4. View details 

5. Click on the tab relating to the relevant project stage (e.g. 'Invitation to Tender') 

6. Click on the 'Attach Documents' button and upload your return. 

7. Check ALL your response documents are uploaded and displayed in the 'My Tender Return' panel. The system will only permit your organisation to make one return. 

8. Click the red 'Submit Return' button. 

Please note, to preserve the integrity of the procurement, all communications with the University must be made via the correspondence function within In-Tend. 

Publication of Award Details: In accordance with Regulation 50, paragraph (2) of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 and subject to Article 5 and Annex 5, Part D (13) of Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council (if applicable), the University intends to publish the value of any resulting contract at the award stage, and reserves the right to do so. By submitting a response, potential suppliers/tenderers are consenting to publication of this information unless otherwise agreed in advance with the University.

Title: Supply of organ retrieval consumables packs
Description:
NHSBT is the commissioner responsible for providing funding, infrastructure, and contract management for the National Organ Retrieval Service. NORS is comprised of several teams based at different transplant centres in England, Wales and Scotland. Teams must be competent to safely retrieve organs for the purpose of life-saving and life-enhancing transplant operations. The objective is for the Authority to be able to purchase specific types of retrieval packs - basic, abdominal and cardiothoracic. These consumables are an essential requirement for the NORS teams to carry out the retrievals. 

NHSBT has awarded The Framework Agreement to Clonallon Laboratories Ltd. The Framework Agreement commenced on the 15th October 2019, the term of this Framework Agreement shall expire 4 years from the Commencement Date. 

The estimated value given below is based on 4 years.

Title: Thamesmead Waterfront Development
Description: Peabody Trust ("Peabody") is seeking a strategic investment and development partner for the regeneration of the area known as Thamesmead Waterfront in South East London ("Site"). The Site has the potential to deliver 11,500 new homes, a rejuvenated town centre with retail, commercial, leisure and educational facilities as part of a comprehensive redevelopment. The partner's role will involve: providing or securing investment; providing strategic advice in relation to the overarching business plan, the masterplan and physical infrastructure; place-making and design services; development delivery, project management, construction management and procurement services; stakeholder engagement and consultation services; advice in relation to the long-term management of the Site; and advice on the marketing and disposal of development parcels. The opportunity may also involve managing developed assets held by the JV partnership and/or by Peabody to generate income streams.

Organisation Name: East Of England NHS Collaborative Hub
Title: Independent Investigation Services for the NHS
Description:
The NHS is required under the NHS Serious Incident Framework/Patient Safety Framework (and/or any iterations) and the Department of Health Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights and the investigation of serious incidents to commission an independent investigation.

The NHS has created a Framework for Independent Investigation Services that meets the technical and geographic requirements for the NHS. This framework agreement provides a flexible and responsive framework to enable the NHS to comply with the NHS Serious Incident Framework.

The framework Agreement is split into five lots:

Lot 1 - Independent Expert Investigations
Lot 2 - Partnership Investigations
Lot 3 - Local Care System Investigations
Lot 4 - Health & Social Care & Partners Investigations
Lot 5 - Systematic Independent Investigations
Bidders will continue to have the opportunity to apply to join the Framework Agreement on an annual basis.

It is anticipated that applications will be accepted on the following dates:

May 2020 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2020
May 2021 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2021
May 2022 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2022
May 2023 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2023
May 2024 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2024 (dependent on extension of Framework Agreement)
May 2025 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2025 (dependent on extension of Framework Agreement)

The Services to which this Procurement relates fall within Schedule 3 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (the "Regulations"). As such, the procurement of the Services has been run as a bespoke, Open Process Procedure, involving the completion of a Qualification Questionnaire to qualify for acceptance onto the Framework Agreement. Successful bidders will be asked to participate in Mini Competitions for contracts for lots in which they have been successful or may be subject to the direct award of a contract.

Attain has conducted this procurement exercise as agent for and on behalf of the Contracting Authority (the NHS) and in partnership with East of England Collaborative Procurement Hub (EoECPH). 

The contract will be for an initial 48 months (indicative contract value for 48 months is £10,000,000 GBP), with the option to extend for a further 24 months (indicative contract value for 60 months is £15,000,000 GBP).
Contact Address 1: The NHS Commissioning Board, Skipton House, 80 London Road

Title: DELIVERY OF THE NATIONAL ASSESSMENT AND ACCREDITATION SYSTEM (NAAS) FOR CHILD AND FAMILIES SOCIAL WORKERS Contract Award Notice
Description:
NAAS is now in its second phase of delivery with 56 local authorities and Trusts on-board. 
The demand from the sector to join as early adopters means the project is now very different to how it looked two years ago, when the last procurement was carried out.
This procurement exercise is to ensure that the successful delivery of NAAS to date is built on, and a delivery partner is in place to deliver all that we need in phase 2 between September 2019 and March 2020.
The incumbent supplier will provide a full handover to the new supplier. 
This tender is for:
- Management of the whole NAAS assessment delivery system including
o Operational delivery of NAAS assessment centres, which includes delivery of practice simulation with actors
o Continuation of existing digital platform
o Governance of the service
o Delivery of a minimum of 800 high quality assessments to a maximum of 1950 high quality assessments between September 2019 and March 2020
- Monthly light touch support and universal communications offer to NAAS site employers
- Collaborative working with users, stakeholders and partners
To ensure the continued delivery of assessment centres, 65 centres have been booked for the period September 2019-December 2019, using additional funding outside of this contract to pay for; venues, staff (a centre manager, assessment facilitators, assessors and actors) and logistical arrangements for the IT equipment to be delivered to the centres by courier. Information about these booked assessment centres will be handed over to the successful supplier as part of the implementation period.
Attachments: NAAS Contract-Redacted Final.pdf

Organisation Name: Department of Health and Social Care
Title: Express Freight Services
Description:
The Department of Health and Social Care (the Authority) has engaged the services of three organisations to provide the Authority with assured access to an express freight capability to maintain the uninterrupted supply of medicines and medical products where there is an urgent need or where a suppliers' own logistics arrangements are disrupted. Key elements of the requirement include: mobilisation of service, capacity assurance, capacity flexibility, managed service, supplier services & value for money. The Authority's aim is to have the services fully operational by 24th October 2019 to allow for testing in advance of full operational sign off by the 31st October 2019.

Title: Agile Security Testing
Description:
Universal Credit is a flagship service for the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP), and given its accessibility on the Internet, the service is subject to a range of evolving threats.
With agile methodologies, and the use of commodity cloud services, the need to rapidly iterate deployed applications and infrastructures is paramount in order to meet the needs of users.
In such a fast-paced environment, it is therefore increasingly crucial that there is a comprehensive application testing regime in place, aligned with the development lifecycle, to ensure that vulnerabilities are identified and prioritised accordingly for remediation.
The Universal Credit Programme requires a culture of continuous vulnerability assessment to align with the existing continuous integration (CI) pipeline.  The DWP therefore require an Agile Security Testing service  to complement our developers, DevOps and the Secure Design team to continuously test existing and new features as they iterate to feed into the Development lifecycle.
The supplier will be required to undertake a combination of automated and manual testing to identify vulnerabilities within the application. In addition, the supplier is also required to utilise and optimise existing toolsets used for the identification of application vulnerabilities and suggest areas for improvement.
Attachments: Agile Security Testing 2019 redacted.pdf

Organisation Name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust
Title: Home With Support (East Kent)
Description:
Kent Community NHS Health Foundation Trust (KCHFT) is seeking tenders from suitable experienced providers who can deliver a Home with Support Service. 
The Home with Support Service supports the discharge of patients who have been assessed in the Acute as safe to go home by receiving a further assessment of need, rehabilitation and a period of recovery at home and develop a plan of care and onward referral if required. 
This service is an extension of the KCHFT Rapid Transfer of Care Service, and will work in collaboration with Rapid Response, Acute Response Team, Rehabilitation teams to support patients with complex need to be transferred home from either the Accident and Emergency Dept. (Front Door) or Wards (Back Door) from an Acute Hospital or from a KCHFT Community Hospital bed. Short term support may also be required for patients who may need a period of additional care to enable them to remain at home and avoid a hospital admission. 
KCHFT is looking to work with social care providers to support the identified care needs as part of the discharge plan of care for the patient.  
The initial delivery model, per block, consists of a volume of hours. Blocks will be 'single handed' for the months June through October and 'double handed' November through May' unless otherwise directed. 
The Contract will run until the end of March 2020, unless terminated in accordance with the Terms and Conditions. There are two options to extend the Contract Term by 12 months (March 2021) and a further 12 months (March 2022). 
Expressions of interest will only be accepted via the Trust Procurement Portal.
KCHFT is undertaking this Procurement activity under the Competitive Procedure with Negotiation and Light Touch Regime. 
Indicative Procurement Timetable: 
Event	Anticipated Date
Closing Date and Time for Tender Submissions	Midday Friday 28th June 2019
Tender Evaluation Period	Monday 8th July - 29th July 2019 (Including any need for negotiation) 
Contract Award	Monday 5th August 2019
Mobilisation	Monday 19th August 19 - Monday 2nd September 19
Contract Commencement Date	Monday 19th August 2019
Lots
The service is split into seven Lots:
•	South Kent Coast North
•	South Kent Coast South
•	Canterbury & Coastal North
•	Canterbury & Coastal South
•	Ashford North
•	Ashford South
•	Thanet

Title: The Provision of Housing Related Floating Support Services
Description:
Haringey Council ("the Council") invites tenders from suitably experienced and qualified providers to deliver the provision of Housing Related Floating Support Services to Haringey residents.

The service will be procured in two lots:

•	Lot 1 - Floating Support for Families at Risk of Homelessness
•	Lot 2 - Floating Support for Adults at Risk of Homelessness 

Tenderers' may tender for more than one lot.

Please note that the Tenderers applying for these contracts must have minimum of 3 years proven experience of delivering homelessness prevention and/or housing related support services.

The maximum annual budget available for these Contracts is £390,000 for Lot 1 and £780,000 for Lot 2, excluding VAT.  Any bids above these annual figures and/or below the minimum support hour stated in Service Specifications for each Lot will not be considered.
Additional Text:
The contract period for all Lots will be for three (3) years with an option to extend for further period/periods of up to a total of four (4) years in accordance with the terms and conditions of the contract.  For avoidance of doubt, the maximum length of the contracts, if extended, will not exceed seven (7) years subject to satisfactory performance.

The contract will be awarded to the Most Economically Advantageous Tender (MEAT) in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015.  MEAT for this contract is quality 70% and Price 30%.  Tender submissions will be subject to minimum quality thresholds.

Title: WAV PT - The Provision of Grounds Maintenance Services - AWARD
Description:
Waverley Borough Council is one of 11 Districts and Boroughs in the county of Surrey. The council has an annual turnover of £60 million, employs over 450 staff and provides more than 110 services to a population of 121,000. Waverley Borough encompasses an area of 345km2, containing 730km of road and 52,750 properties. The Waverley Borough Council will invitesTenders for the management and maintenance of its parks and open spaces for a period of 5 years with possible extension of two further terms (possible total of 15years (5+5+5), with the first term commencing 1st November 2019 and ending on 31st October 2024). 
      
      The grounds maintenance contract maintains green spaces across the Borough; including parks and recreation grounds, sports facilities, countryside sites, housing estates, sheltered housing units, car parks, leased properties, council offices, cemeteries, toilets, pavilions and Surrey County Council highway verges and road areas. 
      
      The contracts specification covers; grass cutting, shrub, rose, herbaceous borders, hedges and scrub maintenance, sports pitch and facility maintenance, sports pitch booking service, toilet and changing room cleaning, bin emptying and litter picking, playground inspection and repairs, cemetery operations, hard surface maintenance, weed control, water course and ditch maintenance, park keepers, roving patrols at weekends and an out of hours and emergency cover provision. 
      
      The tender will be run via the Restricted procedure in accordance with the Public Contract Regulations 2015. Bidders will be able to submit a Selection Questionnaire (SQ), following the assessment of which, bidders will be short listed and progressed to the Invitation to Tender stage (ITT). 
      
      The contract will be awarded on a fixed price basis; bidders will be scored solely on their quality response at tender stage. The rationale behind a fixed price tender is to focus the tenderer purely on the quality of service provision. The budget will be approximately £1,175,000 and CPI will be applied on an annual basis. Bids priced in excess of the stated budget will be rejected. 
      
      There is £50,000 available in addition to the annual budget, as a reward for achieving the performance targets agreed at the beginning of the Contract and each year thereafter. We wish to ensure there is a constant focus on delivering quality and to incentivise the appointed contractor to continually seek improvements and efficiency gains in their delivery. We hope this will provide the opportunity to promote and develop a creative and innovative thinking approach from a contractor, with our residents and tenants at the heart of this.

Title: DFID 8516 Stopping Abuse and Female Exploitation (SAFE) Programme - Zimbabwe Contract Award
Description:
The overall programme's purpose is to:
a. Prevent violence by changing harmful attitudes and behaviours towards women and girls, providing life skills training to confront abuse, providing advisory services to inform about sexual and reproductive health and rights; providing community education and training on violence prevention and response; and providing parenting support on non-violent disciplining techniques.
b. Respond to violence by increasing service uptake by survivors, strengthening community justice structures, providing rehabilitation and reintegration services for victims, and providing relationship counselling to victims of child marriage and domestic abuse.
c. Increase the availability and use of evidence to better reach the most vulnerable people in Zimbabwe by conducting an evaluation of violence prevention and response activities to optimise activities' cost-effectiveness, commissioning demand-led research on child marriage, modern slavery and other topics with limited data, and delivering capacity building activities to improve data use of implementing partners. The evaluation and learning component of the SAFE programme will be separately procured under a DFID framework agreement (GEFA) to ensure independence impartiality from the GBV component.

Title: Energy Company Obligation (ECO) Evaluation: Household Survey
Description:
***PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS IS NOT A CALL FOR COMPETITION***

The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy had a requirement to collect evidence from households receiving a measure under ECO to fill existing evidence gaps.
ECO3 is the most focused of the supplier obligation schemes to-date, with funding more narrowly targeted than previously at households who are low-income, vulnerable and at risk of fuel poverty. This focus places an increased need for BEIS to demonstrate which households receive ECO measures. Household demographics are therefore a research priority and feature strongly in the research questions listed below.
As set out in the introduction section, the policy is at a key point in its development cycle. The Clean Growth Strategy has committed to funding domestic energy efficiency until 2028 at least at current ECO levels, however, the current ECO3 scheme is due to expire in 2022.

The requirement was advertised on the BEIS Research and Evaluation Framework Lot 3

The service will provide housing support to socially excluded vulnerable adults who do not meet the social care threshold and include but not limited to the following groups:

•	Substance misusers

•	Offenders

The service provider will be required to work in conjunction with Royal Greenwich Housing, Community Safety, Public Health, Adult Services, Clinical Commissioning Group, Social Landlords, Private Landlords, other partners and service users to provide a service that meets the outcomes outlined in the specification and will consider all opportunities to enhance the experience of the socially excluded vulnerable adults who use the service.

Description:
A framework for the supply of science resources and equipment suitable for use in primary and secondary education. A fully comprehensive range is required, including class kits, lab ware, scientific equipment and instruments, as well as a complete range of chemicals suitable for use in experiments relevant to the delivery of the secondary science curriculum. Goods are for delivery to the ESPO central distribution centre (Leicester) and also for delivery directly to individual customer establishments.

Lot 1: Primary Education Science - Products required include a comprehensive range of primary education science-based class kits and other primary science resources suitable for the delivery of the curriculum for Key Stages 1 and 2.  Goods are for delivery to ESPO, Leicester, and also to individual ESPO customers.  It is envisaged that this Lot will be awarded to one supplier.  ESPO will require catalogue support from the awarded supplier including but not limited to: product selection, product images and descriptions.

Lot 2: Secondary Education Science - Products required include a comprehensive range of primary education science-based class kits and other primary science resources suitable for the delivery of the curriculum for Key Stages 3 and 4.  Goods are for delivery to ESPO, Leicester, and also to individual ESPO customers.  It is envisaged that this Lot will be awarded to one supplier.  ESPO will require catalogue support from the awarded supplier including but not limited to: product selection, product images and descriptions, and safety information for chemicals.

The framework agreement has the option to extend for up to a further 24 months. The total estimated value stated includes the option period.

Title: Framework for the Supply and Delivery of CBRN Protective Clothing
Description:
The UK Police Service used to have two ensembles of personal protective equipment (PPE) for use in response to an incident involving a chemical, biological, radiological or nuclear (CBRN) agent, and these were the CR1 and QuickDon (QDPPE). Materials from which these two suits are manufactured have been discontinued by the supplier (WL Gore) and the manufacturer (Remploy Frontline Limited) is no longer trading. CR1 has successfully been withdrawn and stocks of the QDPPE have begun to deplete as their ten-year shelf-life recommended by the manufacturer approaches. 

Both The National CBRN Centre and Home Office, Office for Security and Counter-Terrorism (OSCT) have identified the need to consider Police CBRN PPE requirements in the context of preparing for emergencies involving contaminants that may have been deliberately or accidentally released and emergencies that may involve elements of more than one terrorist attack planning scenario.                                                         This project is critical to the National CBRN Response Framework which aims to ensure the UK is prepared to mitigate the unique consequences of CBRN emergencies - specifically contamination. CBRN PPE is essential to the success of this programme because it allows emergency responders to operate relatively safely within a potentially contaminated area.
Contact Address 1: Police Headquarters, Lloyd House, Colmore Circus Q

Title: Service Level Agreement for the operation and maintenance services of existing Combined Heat and Power Plant and associated ancillary systems
Description:
The University of Southampton Estates and Facilities Department has a requirement to maintain to a high performance standard its existing CHP system and electrical outputs located at University Road, Highfield, Southampton SO17 1BJ, (Highfield Campus). 
This requirement requires the provision of a comprehensive maintenance service including remote monitoring, regular performance reporting and a CHP performance guarantee. 
The CHP installation comprises of 2 No. 1400kW[e] natural gas fired CHP engines type JMS420GSN as manufactured by Jenbacher and were installed in 2005 and have been fully operational since that time. The CHP plant has been maintained in accordance with the manufacturers' requirements with the correct level of service / overhaul being carried out at the key milestone (hours run) stages. All records are available for review including past performance reports. 
(It should be noted that during the major overhaul at 60,000 hours, the crankshafts for both engines were inspected and were deemed to be of a condition that did not require them to be replaced at that time).
Additional Text:
Additional information on how to apply for this contract

https://in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofsouthampton/aspx/

The University is utilising an electronic tendering tool (In-Tend: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofsouthampton) to manage this Soft market exercise. All documentation in relation to this tender can be downloaded from the In-Tend portal. 

Interested suppliers are advised that there will be no hard copy documents issued to organisations and all communications with the University, all communications will be conducted via the In-Tend portal. Regular monitoring of the portal is the responsibility of the supplier.

If you are not already registered as a supplier with the University of Southampton, you will need to register in In-Tend in order to access the tender documentation. 

Once you have logged in as a supplier: click on 'Tenders'; locate the relevant project; and click 'View Details'. Once you are in the project screen, you will be able to register your company against the project and access all documentation by clicking 'Express Interest'.

Interested suppliers are advised that formal expressions of interest in the project must be by way of completion and return of the relevant soft market exercise return documents via the In-Tend portal.

Further instructions for the submission of Invitation to Tender responses are below. 
To submit your return, please follow the instructions below:
1. Log In
2. Click 'Tenders'
3. Locate the relevant project
4. View Details
5. Click on the tab relating to the relevant project stage (e.g. 'Prior Information Notice')
6. Click on the 'Attach Documents' button and upload your return.
7. Check ALL your response documents are uploaded and displayed in the "My Tender Return" panel. The system will only permit your organisation to make one return.
8. Click the red "Submit Return" button. 
Please note that, to preserve the integrity of the tendering procedure, all queries must made be via the correspondence function within the In-Tend portal.

In accordance with Regulation 50, paragraph (2) of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 and subject to Article 5 and Annex 5, Part D (13) of Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council (if applicable), the University intends to publish the value of any resulting contract at the award stage, and reserves the right to do so. By submitting a tender response, bidders are consenting to publication of this information unless otherwise agreed in advance with the University.

Due to the nature of this project, it has been deemed unsuitable for division into lots. The risk of dividing the requirement would render the execution of the contract excessively technically difficult, not cost effective and would undermine the proper execution of the contract.

Title: DFID 8566 Action on Children's Harmful Work in African Agriculture (ACHA) Contract Award
Description:
The outcomes will be that policies and interventions are better designed and targeted at the forms of harmful work children do in African agriculture and how to effectively create conditions for children to thrive. This will avoid misguided actions that worsen working conditions and prospects for children. The ultimate impacts will be a reduction in the number of children in harmful work and the
prevention of future harmful children's work in African agriculture. This will contribute to Sustainable Development Goal 8.7 and the elimination of child labour by 2025. The programme will facilitate the creation of conditions for children and youth to thrive and reach
their potential, which will contribute to the unlocking of a demographic dividend in Africa.

Title: London and Quadrant Housing Trust - Build London Partnership and Asset Management Main Contractors Framework 2019 - 2023 - AWARD
Description:
London and Quadrant Housing Trust and its subsidiary Quadrant Construction Services are one of the largest providers of affordable housing in the UK, housing over 250,000 people in more than 95,000 homes, primarily across London and the South East of England. London and Quadrant Housing Trust are tendering for the provision of Build London Partnership and Assets Management Main Contractors or London and Quadrant's Self Delivered New Build Projects to comply with the Public Contracts regulations 2015. The objective of this tender process is to establish a Framework Agreement with the tenderers and London and Quadrant Housing Trust. The dates and contract value are estimates and could be subject to change. This is tender is for Main Contractors. 
      
      This is a two stage tender and both stages adhere to the time-scales as prescribed within the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 for Restricted OJEU Tenders.
      
      Stage 1: Selection Stage
      
      Click on the 'Express Interest' Button at the bottom
      
      Click on the 'Selection Stage' Tab at the top
      - Scroll to the bottom of the screen and you will be able to view the Tender Documents and access the Standard Selection Questionnaire
      - For the Selection Stage you will only need to submit the Standard Selection Questionnaire
      - We will score your questionnaire and will advise you as to whether you are successful or not
      - Pricing Documents will only be available to those who have passed the Selection Stage
      
      
      ONLY IF YOU HAVE PASSED THE SELECTION STAGE 
      
      Stage 2: ITT Stage
      
      - Click on the 'ITT' Tab 
      - Scroll to the bottom and you will be able to access the Tender Documents
      - Tenderers will be briefed as to what they will need to submit for this tender
      
      Please allow sufficient time to submit your return by the specified dates as late returns will not be permitted. 
      
      
      Under the Framework Agreement L&Q and all companies within the L&Q Group (including, without limitation, Quadrant Construction Services) will have the option to call-off contracts with individual framework contractors as and when required. In addition, other Social Housing Providers in the UK (both those that are in existence now and those that may be in existence in the future) will also be entitled to call-off contracts under the Framework Agreement. "Social Housing Provider" for this purpose means any provider of social housing and includes, without limitation, Registered Providers, Local Authorities and ALMOs. Such Social Housing Providers will only be entitled to call off under the Framework Agreement if L&Q consents.
      
      For information regarding this tender please contact the Framework Team via the tender portal. This tender is managed by the Framework Buying department. Please do not contact any other department within the London and Quadrant Group. Please do not contact Group Procurement for information as this Tender has been created by the Framework Buying Department.

Title: Legal Services - Development Division project
Description:
This procurement activity relates to the provision of legal services as described as follows:

- the provision of legal services related to potentially generally high value and/or complex corporate real estate transactions;
- the provision of legal services related specifically to the potential corporate acquisitions of two strategic land and/or housebuilding companies, and;
- the provision of legal services relating to alternative structures that would satisfy L&Q's strategic ambitions.

L&Q is seeking a suitably qualified and experienced Service Provider to provide high quality Services supported by robust management and quality control processes. Tenderers will need to demonstrate that they have the requisite skills, infrastructure, resources and procedures already in place to perform the Contract to the standard
required by L&Q. Examples of the standard expected of the Service Provider are:
- being able to self-audit all aspects of the Services to ensure that consistently high levels of service are attained, including quality checks on personnel,
- providing accurate and detailed cost information to enable forward planning and budget forecasting on a quarterly basis,
- taking responsibility for ensuring L&Q's compliance with current legislation for all aspects of the Services as far as their work activities are concerned,

Title: Operational Ration Heater Systems (ORHS)
Description:
The requirement is for an Operational Ration Heater System (ORHS) which consists of portable metal stoveand solid fuel blocks to enable an individual to boil water and heat military field rations in a range of weatherconditions. The solid fuel must be Ethanol based (Bio-Fuel) any other fuels such as Hexamine will not beaccepted.
1: Heating Performance - The ORHS must be capable of boiling 500ml water to a temperature of 100C instandard issue MOD equipment (mess tins) within 11 minutes at an air temperature of -8C to +40C and sustainthe temperature for a period of 5 minutes.
2: Tactical Performance - The ORHS must function within 10 minutes of being immersed in water, this is to allowindividuals to prepare a meal after wading through water.
3: Tactical Performance - The ORHS must be as small and light as possible. The total weight (Stove & Fuel)must be max. 330g with sufficient fuel to heat a total of 6 meals or hot drinks.
4: Tactical Performance - The ORHS fuel must be tactically viable - smoke, noise, smell and light must be keptto a minimum.
5: Tactical Performance - The ORHS must be able to operate in poor climatic conditions and operate in wet andwindy weather.
6: Compatibility - The ORHS must be compatible with VIRTUS and OSPREY utility pouch and must be carriedin a utility pouch (16.5cm x 10cm x 7.5cm) and still b able to heat a minimum of 6 meals or hot drinks in a 24Hrperiod
7: Safety - The ORHS must be able to be safely transported in bulk by rail, air, road or sea.

Aims and objectives of service

Title: Targeted Assurance Review
Description:
The ORR are seeking support from a suitably informed consultant who has a demonstrable knowledge of UK rail infrastructure standards and procedures regarding management and structural assessment of structures. 
The requirements for the assessment of structures on the railway were given in NR/SP/CIV/035: Assessment of Structures (NR, 2004). Network Rail's standard adopted a two stage assessment process comprising of Level 1 and Level 2 assessment. Level 1, the simplest level, and Level 2 typically including advanced methods of structural analysis.  
In 2011 Network Rail developed an assessment technique to support the rapid delivery of an Assessment Programme which covered 13,431 bridge assessments across the network. The new assessment technique is described as a Level 0 assessment. 
The Level 0 assessment is a simplified assessment based on principal checks of critical sections and conservative load distribution. First time assessment of structures using a Level 0 approach is generally based on recorded information and supplementary site investigations as determined by the Asset Engineer.
We require the successful consultant to review the use of the Level 0 tool, assessment processes and its impact in the asset's long term management as set out in 2.2.

Description:

Expressions of interest start date: 17/06/2019
Return of tenders/bids end date: 16 July 2019
Initial Contract Duration: 28 Weeks
Extensions: 0
Estimated Contract Value (including extensions): £800,000
Description: A new development of 53 flats in 3 blocks will be built on Collingwood Estate in 2019/2020. The new development requires some of the existing district heating services to be modified and re-routed to the existing plantrooms.
Works will consist of works to the existing culvert, working in confined spaces, stripping out of old services, digging new trenches for new mains pipework, works to the plantrooms and hard & soft landscaping works.
The project is located within the Collingwood Estate residential housing estate situated within the road/street boundaries of Barnsley Street to the north, Collingwood Street to the west, Darling Row to the south and Cambridge Heath Road (A107) to the east. Headlam Street bisects the estate running east/west.
There will be works within the plant rooms of existing residential buildings and these buildings will be occupied whilst the works are being carried out.

Additional Information:

Organisations must ensure that access to the system is available to their representatives dealing with the contract and that this contact is updated as and when required. 
The council will not be liable for the lack of delegated access within the organisation and will not send any documentation regarding the opportunity, which shall be exclusively available through the portal.

Suppliers are responsible for allowing sufficient time to submit their Application. The Council accepts no liability whatsoever for tenders that are not submitted due to internet connectivity issues, transmission delays or errors.

Title: Exchequer Services
Description:
The London Borough of Bromley are seeking tenders for it's Exchequer Services. There are various elements to the Exchequer Services Contract.
                                                                                                                                                                                                           The services this contract comprises of are noted below.
•	Business Rates 
•	Council Tax
•	Housing Benefit & Council Tax Support/ Reduction
•	Sundry Debtors, Mortgages & Debt Management
•	Payroll
•	Pensions
•	Cashiers & Postal Services 
•	Cash Collections
•	Accounts Payable
•	Customer services
•	Financial Assessment & Charging
•	Appointee and Deputyship
•	Schools Finance
•	Schools Human Resources Provision (Statutory Services) - Community and Voluntary Controlled Schools
•	Schools Human Reources Provision (Statutory Services) - Foundation and Voluntary Aided Schools
•       IT                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     The tender opportunity will be run electronically through the London Tenders Portal and suppliers will need to register their company with the portal as soon as possible (if they have not already done so) at www.londontenders.org to ensure they are able to access and submit the relevant documents online. All applications must be made through the London Tenders Portal only and not to the Contact Details contained within this notice.                                                                                                           
Tenderers should note that the London Borough of Bexley are tendering their Revenue service and if any tenderers choose to submit a bid for both the London Borough of Bexley (Lot 1) and the London Borough of Bromley (Lot 2), tenderers will have the opportunity, should they so choose, to offer a simple percentage discount to their tendered contract price for each Council (with no change in the services detailed in the specifications).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
Tenderers should note that the London Borough of Bexley ("Bexley")(Lot 1) and the London Borough of Bromley ("Bromley")(Lot 2)  are each running their own independent procurement process, including evaluation.  Bromley's and Bexley's respective specifications and requirements are different from each other - this is not a joint tender but two separate and independent tenders with alignment of the tender timetables.

Title: Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning Services for CSSF West Africa
Description:
The specific aims of this contract are:
1.	Refining current systems and approach: There is a recognised need to strengthen the West Africa CSSF's approach to measuring results and impact and to support the alignment of all programmes with their overarching strategies. This will include the review of existing processes and mapping out the necessary steps to bring improvements; including promoting adaptive management techniques and the creative use of Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) tools in order to maximise the impact of tailored M&E support
2.	Taking forward a portfolio approach to measuring effects and impact: the supplier will assist HMG in delivering improved M&E processes across projects, programmes and in particular at the portfolio level to ensure accurate capture of our activities outputs, outcomes and impact.  Further, the supplier will develop an approach to build a stronger understanding of the value for money of CSSF programmes in West Africa
3.	Learning: We aim to build a robust evidence base to strengthen learning and an understanding of what works and why at project, programme and portfolio level as well as across specific thematic areas, such as gender, relevant across West Africa. This includes better capturing the impact, synergies, added value and challenges of cross-departmental cooperation on conflict, stability and security in West Africa.
4.	Technical assistance: We wish to building the capability of HMG staff and our implementing partners (International NGOs, national NGOs, Multilaterals and private sector organisations) to better design, implement and monitor CSSF funded work. This will require the supplier to provide hands on support in creating M&E tools. Technical advice is also required through the provision of ongoing M&E advice through an M&E adviser position provided by the supplier.
Contact Address 1: Commercial Directorate, Foreign and Commonwealth Office, King Charles Street
